prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Coordination with other federal proceedings

para.paratext: Another geographic factor considered by the Panel has been the potential for coordinating the actions to be transferred with other proceedings pending in the federal courts. The Panel has, for example, considered the pendency of a related criminal antitrust action in selecting a transferee district for a group of civil actions arising from the same course of conduct.[1] Similarly, the venue of pending government civil antitrust litigation may be of interest to the Panel.[2] This is important because the statute does not permit the Panel to transfer the government case.[3] In one case the Panel observed:

It is apparent that a great deal of coordination will be necessary between the discovery which all plaintiffs seek here and the proceedings in the United States' action. Tremendous success has been achieved in other multidistrict litigation, such as the Government Auto Fleet Litigation, through the cooperation of all the judges and parties involved in coordinating discovery in the private treble damage actions with that in the Government criminal and civil actions. Because neither of the Government actions is subject to transfer under Section 1407, such coordination in this litigation can best be achieved by transferring all actions to the [district in which the government actions are pending].[4]

By an even stronger argument, where there are both civil and criminal government actions pending, the Panel will be inclined to select the district in which they are pending as the transferee district.[5]

The Panel's preference for selecting a district where related grand jury proceedings are taking place reflects a number of considerations of judicial management.[6] The choice of that district permits the coordination between the proceedings.[7] That district is also a district where relevant documents are located in most cases where related grand jury proceedings are taking place, so transfer to that district is logical even in the absence of the potential for coordination. Even if there is no action pending, but the Panel is aware of a pending federal grand jury investigation with information requests overlapping with the discovery being conducted in the civil litigation before it, the Panel will be inclined to transfer to a district where coordination between the matters can occur.[8] The pendency of related litigation, even where the actions are different in nature may present the potential for coordination and may drive the selection of a particular district.[9] This factor does not trump all other considerations in selection of a district. In one case the Panel acknowledged federal grand jury proceedings in the Northern District of California, but found the pendency of the majority of the actions in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, the preference of the parties for that district, and the location of the largest producers of the products at issue were more compelling.[10]

The Panel may also transfer cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in a district where bankruptcy or reorganization proceedings involving one of the parties are taking place.[11] The Panel has noted in these decisions that the trustee normally has possession of all the documents and records of the party in reorganization, thereby making that district an especially appropriate transferee district.[12] This factor is not applied automatically, however, and the selection of another district is not foreclosed.[13] In one case the Panel declined to transfer the cases to the district where the bankruptcy proceedings were pending because of the greater familiarity with the litigation held by a judge in another district.[14] The Panel has stated that a potential conflict exists between the rehabilitative purpose of the bankruptcy laws and the interest of a transferee judge under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 in expediting the pretrial handling of the transferred cases.[15] For that reason, the Panel is likely to transfer cases to a different judge than the judge presiding over the bankruptcy case even if it does transfer the cases to the same district. The fact that a different judge would be assigned makes it less important that the cases be assigned to the same district. The Panel has also ordered transfer of adversary proceedings in bankruptcy in order to permit coordination with other civil litigation pending in a district other than where the bankruptcy proceeding giving rise to the adversary proceedings.[16]

Even the location of prior government actions may be considered by the Panel in the selection of a transferee district. In one case the Panel transferred the actions to a district where prior SEC enforcement proceedings had taken place.[17] Similarly, the location of former federal antitrust criminal proceedings[18] or the location of a governmental investigation[19] may be a factor in selection of a transferee district. The location of pending qui tam actions has been noted by the Panel as a reason to select a particular jurisdiction.[20]

The Panel has also considered the pendency of actions involving similar, though unrelated, issues.[21] This factor relates essentially to a presumed special experience and ability of the judge handling the similar litigation. The transferee court might also gain insight from handling a related or similar MDL docket.[22]

Coordination of proceedings is the hallmark of management of complex and multiple litigation. Accordingly, the opportunity to facilitate coordination of multidistrict litigation with other federal proceedings will only rarely be passed up by the Panel. If the Panel determines another district is an appropriate transferee district, there usually will be strong factors favoring that district.[23]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re American Express Anti-Steering Rules Antitrust Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1343 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Ampicillin Antitrust Litigation, 315 F. Supp. 317, 318–19 (J.P.M.L. 1970). But see In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796, 800 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See, e.g., In re Androgel Antitrust Litigation (No. II), 655 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Cuisinart Food Processor Antitrust Litigation, 506 F. Supp. 651, 655 (J.P.M.L. 1981); In re Folding Carton Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 384, 386 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1271, 1274 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(g) (1982). See, e.g., In re Toilet Seat Antitrust Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 1342, 1344 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Ampicillin Antitrust Litigation, 315 F. Supp. 317, 319 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
In re Toilet Seat Antitrust Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 1342, 1344 (J.P.M.L. 1975). The citation is to In re Government Auto Fleet Sales, 328 F. Supp. 218 (J.P.M.L. 1971).

See, e.g., In re Liquid Aluminum Sulfate Antitrust Litigation, 159 F. Supp. 3d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2016); In re: TelexFree Securities Litigation, 54 F. Supp. 3d 1353 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Automotive Wire Harness Systems Antitrust Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Refco Securities Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Human Tissue Products Liability Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Xyberbaut Corp. Securities Litigation, 403 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Folding Carton Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 384, 386 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Sugar Industry Antitrust Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 1271, 1274 (J.P.M.L. 1975) (five related government actions).

See, e.g., In re Foundry Resins Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Lupron Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 180 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2001); In re Automotive Refinishing Paint Antitrust Litigation, 177 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2001).
See In re Cuisinart Food Processor Antitrust Litigation, 506 F. Supp. 651, 655 (J.P.M.L. 1981).
See In re Fine Paper Antitrust Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 759, 762 (J.P.M.L. 1978).

See In re Lumber Liquidators Chinese-Manufactured Flooring Products Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2015) (district where factually related securities action chosen for product liability actions).
In re Hydrogen Peroxide Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2005).

See, e.g., In re Sunedison, Inc., Securities Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1350 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re: TelexFree Securities Litigation, 54 F. Supp. 3d 1353 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: General Motors LLC Ignition Switch Litigation, 26 F. Supp. 3d 1390 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Refco Securities Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re ClassicStar Mare Lease Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Gross Common Carrier, Inc., Freight Undercharge Claims Litigation, 843 F. Supp. 1506 (J.P.M.L. 1994); In re American Continental Corporation/Lincoln Sav. and Loan Securities Litigation, 130 F.R.D. 475 (J.P.M.L. 1990); In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225, 230 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Natural Resources Fund, Inc., Securities Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1403, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 221 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1021 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Westec Corp., 307 F. Supp. 559 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
See, e.g., In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 221 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1021 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See, e.g., In re Food Fair Securities Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1301, 1306 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
See In re Stirling Homex Corp. Securities Litigation, 388 F. Supp. 567, 569–70 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
See, e.g., In re Multidistrict Litigation Involving Banking Agreements with Stirling Homex Corp., 388 F. Supp. 572, 573 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
See In re Phar-Mor, Inc., Securities Litigation, 1994 WL 41830 (J.P.M.L. 1994).
See In re Value Line Special Situations Fund Litigation, 334 F. Supp. 999 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See, e.g., In re Scientific Control Corp. Securities Litigation, 380 F. Supp. 791, 793 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re West Coast Bakery Flour Antitrust Litigation, 368 F. Supp. 808 (J.P.M.L. 1974).
See, e.g., In re Foundry Resins Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

See, e.g., In re Celexa and Lexapro Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (transfer to district where two qui tam actions that spawned the MDL ltigation were pending); In re Neurotonin Marketing & Sales Practices Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L.2004) (qui tam case had been pending for 8 years before being settled).
See, e.g., In re Sta-Power Industries Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1398, 1399 (J.P.M.L. 1974).

See, e.g., In re Vonage Marketing and Sales Practices, 505 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Wells Fargo Loan Processor Overtime Pay Litigation, 493 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (“somewhat related” MDL case pending); In re Polychloroprene Rubber (CR) Antitrust Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer to district and judge where prior MDL docket is pending); In re Laughlin Products, Inc., Patent Litigation, 313 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004). In Polychloroprene Rubber the Panel noted that a single transferee judge “will have the flexibility to structure proceedings in both” dockets and that separate proceedings can proceed on separate tracks as the judge deems appropriate. 360 F. Supp. 2d at 1351.

See, e.g., In re Hydrogen Peroxide Antitrust Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer to district other than that where federal grand jury proceedings pending because 1) majority of actions are in distant forum, 2) plaintiffs in tag-alongs favor the distant forum, all responding defendants favor it, and largest domestic defendants located within blocks of the distant courthouse); In re Wiring Device Antitrust Litigation, 444 F. Supp. 1348, 1350 (J.P.M.L. 1978) (advancement of other actions and judicial familiarity appear determinative).
